Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2013–2014
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific, prepared by the Economics and Research 
Department, is one of the annual flagship publications of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
The  publication  provides  the  latest  comprehensive  compendium  and  analysis  of  trends  of 
economic,  social,  financial,  and  Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDG)  indicators  of  ADB’s 
regional members. It also contains a special chapter that provides in-depth, data-intensive 
policy analysis of a prevailing critical policy issue. In general, Key Indicators provides a strong 
data and information support system for evidence-based policy making.  
 
2.  To ensure that the Key Indicators series effectively promotes ADB’s reputation as a 
knowledge institution and serves as a powerful instrument for better informed policies and 
projects, it is essential that rigorous research on the topic selected for the special chapter of Key 
Indicators is conducted along with intensive data validation, analysis, and compilation.1 The 
process will involve extensive collaboration with statistical and other partners, and use of a 
widespread  and  multipronged  approach  in  disseminating  the  resulting  publications.  This 
technical assistance (TA) will ensure that these activities are carried out effectively. The TA’s 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
3.  To complete the shift of the Key Indicators special chapter into a 2-year production cycle 
to allow for more rigorous and systematic analysis, this TA will support the preparation of both 
Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 2014, i.e., the 44th and 45th editions of Key Indicators. 
This is possible since much of the background work for the Key Indicators 2013 special chapter 
is based on staff contributions and financing from the research and development TA, Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2012.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Research on the structural transformation in Asia and the Pacific and its relationship with 
other key challenges in different sectors and aspects is very important given the different levels 
of development progress in the region. The research findings will help in understanding the 
underlying issues, and therefore be useful in designing better policies to manage structural 
transformation that can lead to more inclusive growth and rapid poverty reduction in Asia and 
the Pacific. Background research papers are needed to explore topics related to structural 
transformation, such as the impact of diversification and specialization on economic growth and 
wage levels; the impact of structural transformation on education, energy, and infrastructure 
needs; and key drivers of structural transformation and their policy implications. Higher-income 
Asian  economies  such  as  Hong  Kong,  China;  Japan;  Singapore;  Republic  of  Korea;  and 
Taipei,China have managed to achieve high and sustainable growth that has enabled them to 
move up the income ladder from low-income to high-income economies, bypassing the middle-
income trap in a relatively short period of time. Many other countries have managed to climb 
from low- to middle-income levels but failed to maintain the growth momentum to achieve a 
high-income level. Furthermore, structural change in the Pacific economies presents even more 
challenges that may be explored.  
 
                                                 
1 The special chapter of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2012, Green Urbanization in Asia, discussed the rapid 
urbanization taking place in Asia along with its positive benefits and related emerging challenges, including those 
for the local and global environments. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 31 October 2012. 
3 ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2012. Manila.

2  
5.  As Key Indicators is a premier knowledge product of ADB, its quality must be maintained 
and its contents must be continuously improved. In addition to the special chapter, the latest 
Key Indicators edition contained more than 120 statistical tables of indicators grouped according 
to MDGs; people; economy and output; money, finance, and prices; globalization; transport, 
electricity, and communications; energy and environment; and government and governance.4 A 
short, nontechnical commentary of selected indicators precedes each of the groups. A review of 
the statistical tables will be carried out early to determine whether new indicators need to be 
added  to  ensure  that  users  are  aware  of  emerging  issues,  or  existing  indicators  are 
discontinued to keep the publication from becoming unwieldy. Similarly, the choice of indicators 
to be analyzed in the commentaries will be carefully considered to reflect the impact of current 
developments across different themes.  
 
6.  Key  Indicators  2013  and  Key  Indicators  2014  will  continue  to  feature  the  special 
supplements—the third and fourth editions of the Framework of Inclusive Growth Indicators 
(FIGI).  As  a  significant  contribution  towards  making  inclusive  growth  operational,  the  FIGI 
identified 35 indicators that depict the policy aspects of inclusive growth—economic growth and 
employment opportunities, social inclusion, social protection, as well as good governance and 
institutions. The FIGI is gaining support within and outside ADB, especially in its efforts to go 
beyond  gross  domestic  product  as  a  measure  of  growth  and  well-being.  The  continued 
development and dissemination of the FIGI will support ADB’s thrust to promote inclusive 
growth.  
 
7.  The message and data contents of Key Indicators must be effectively disseminated to its 
target  audience,  which  includes  policy  makers,  statistical  offices,  researchers,  academics, 
journalists,  the  private  sector,  ADB  staff,  regional  and  international  organizations,  and  the 
general  public.  Key  Indicators  is  viewed  as  a  credible  and  valid  source  for  statistics  and 
development policy issues in Asia and the Pacific. Hence, in addition to research for the special 
chapter and to further support research work on the FIGI, the TA will also support expanded 
dissemination of Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 2014 outputs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The main impact of Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 2014 and their supplements 
will be to influence the environment where  economic monitoring and/or policy formulation, 
investment decisions, and new projects based on rigorous evidence-based research findings 
and timely and reliable statistics occur, especially in ADB’s developing member countries.  
 
9.  By the end of the project, Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 2014 will be referred to 
by policy makers and/or economic researchers within and outside Asia, as well as by the 
general public. Improved contents and quality of Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 2014 
will provide (i) information on trends and emerging issues that affect the development status of 
developing member countries; (ii) high-quality data presented in the country, regional, and MDG 
tables; and (iii) indicators of inclusive growth for project planners, policy makers, researchers, 
                                                 
4  The Key Indicators has four parts: Part I – the special chapter; Part II - the MDGs; Part III - the regional tables; and 
Part IV – definitions. Country tables, which are statistical tables containing socioeconomic data of developing 
member countries, Australia, Japan, and New Zealand, are available only on CD-ROM but can also be accessed 
online.

3
and other users. Appendix 2 presents the outline of Key Indicators 2013 and the FIGI. Key 
Indicators 2014 will follow the same outline. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA will support the following key activities of Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 
2014: (i) updating, compiling, and validating data for the country, regional, and MDG tables; (ii) 
preparing background papers including data-intensive research related to the theme chapters 
and the FIGI; (iii) drafting the theme chapter, FIGI, and thematic analysis; (iv) editing, laying out, 
and printing the publications; (v) disseminating the publications; and (vi) analyzing important 
policy issues related to emerging challenges for future special chapters of the Key Indicators 
series.  Following  the  2-year  cycle,  initial  preparations  for  the  Key  Indicators  2015  special 
chapter may also be supported under this TA. 
 
11.  For  Key  Indicators  2013,  the  special  chapter  will  examine  the  issue  of  industry 
diversification and upgrading product sophistication in Asia and the Pacific. For Key Indicators 
2014 the chapter will delve into greater depth on one particular aspect or underlying factor of the 
structural transformation and diversification process, such as the role of education or impacts on 
inequality.5 The studies will also cover key topics pertinent to Asia and the Pacific, such as the 
roles of the manufacturing and service sectors as drivers of growth, the role and emerging 
trends of international trade, and the key determinants for successful transformation from a low-
income to a high-income economy. Examples of related issues include industry policy and other 
government regulations supporting the structural transformation process, the kind of education 
that can prepare skilled workers for obtaining higher value-added and remunerative employment, 
the role of cities as centers of innovation and economic activity, and energy supply and demand 
to support such economic transformation. The discussions will also involve analysis of some 
socioeconomic factors such as health, demographics, and food and energy security and their 
impacts on inclusive growth, inequality, and poverty as a result of the transformation. Overall, 
the studies will provide an evidence-based perspective on what can be done to better support 
economic development and poverty reduction efforts over a period of time and at different levels 
of development.  
 
12.  As part of preparing Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 2014, a series of workshops 
and seminars will be held, with invitees to include prominent researchers, key government 
officials, policy makers, and other key stakeholders. Workshops and seminars are especially 
crucial for (i) developing the special chapters, (ii) firming up the initial findings of the background 
research papers, and (iii) discussing constraints on and the general direction of the special 
chapters.  Background  papers  may  also  be  prepared  for  the  latest  editions  of  the  FIGI 
supplement.  Further,  workshops  and  seminars  may  be  held  to  look  at  the  possibility  of 
harmonizing inclusiveness with development effectiveness by analyzing economies in Asia and 
the Pacific that are making progress in reducing poverty and inequalities. Distinguished experts 
will be invited to give their views so that the outputs of the workshops will be useful in finalizing 
the  Key  Indicators  publications.  Research,  consultations,  and  discussions  with  staff  from 
regional  and  other  departments  within  ADB  will  also  be  conducted  to  further  validate  the 
relevance  of  the  research  findings,  as  well  as  to  identify  emerging  concerns  that  can  be 
potential topics for future Key Indicators publications. 
                                                 
5 The Key Indicators 2013 special chapter and the research and development TA for Policies for Industrial and 
Service Diversification in Asia in the 21st Century are designed to maximize potential synergies. The special 
chapter will focus primarily on the process of structural transformation and its implications, while the TA will focus 
on the role of policies in influencing that process. ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Policies for Industrial and 
Service Diversification in Asia in the 21st Century. Manila.

4  
 
13.  A series of internal meetings and workshops will also be organized to streamline the Key 
Indicators production process. Production bottlenecks to be addressed will include issues such 
as  staff  and  consultant  assignments;  overall  coordination;  development  of  commentaries; 
generation of country, regional, and MDG statistical tables; and consultant recruitment. System 
improvements will also be carried out, including the interlinked processes involving the statistical 
database  system.  Moreover,  the  use  of  C-cube  as  an  additional  platform  for  regular 
communications and data exchanges will be explored, including for sending out Key Indicators 
questionnaires and receiving replies, and for discussion forums including on best practice and 
methods.6 Close monitoring of the Key Indicators process will mitigate the risk of unforeseen 
circumstances that may affect the production schedule. 
   
14.  To improve the quality of Key Indicators, new regional aggregations may be introduced 
in the statistical tables. The aggregations are currently available but are limited to only a few 
indicators.  Compiling  aggregates  using  transparent,  consistent,  and  sound  methods  and 
practices will provide additional value to users. However, this may involve looking at different 
classifications  and  aggregation  practices  used  in  Key  Indicators  in  the  light  of  recent 
socioeconomic  developments  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  and  practices  of  other  international 
organizations, and this may raise complex issues. The TA will support the development of 
methodologies to produce the aggregations. 
 
15.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency of approach across the different parts 
of  Key  Indicators,  the  knowledge  products  will  undergo  stringent  editing  following  ADB’s 
Handbook of Style and Usage.7 Experienced international economics and/or manuscript editors 
will help prepare the publications' special chapters, highlights, and the FIGI. Copy editors will 
edit the regional tables, country tables, FIGI tables, the definitions, and front parts of the 
documents.  
 
16.   The Key Indicators publications will be widely disseminated in coordination with ADB’s 
Department of External Relations. Dissemination will start with an international media launch 
followed by a seminar presentation to key government officials, business people, academe, and 
other research groups. Concurrently, the publications will be uploaded to the ADB website. To 
stimulate more discussion on the issues, outreach activities may also be conducted in selected 
member countries. Background papers will be published separately in ADB’s working paper 
series, the Asian Development Review, or other media at a later date. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency. The Development Indicators and Policy Research 
Division  (ERDI)  will  implement  the  project  in  coordination  with  the  regional  departments, 
resident mission offices, and statistical partners in ADB’s member countries. The project will be 
                                                 
6 C-cube is a set of tools that link members through the web environment within and outside ADB and allow them to 
communicate ideas and insights, coordinate tasks and events, and collaborate by sharing documents or hold 
conferences in different locations. 
7 ADB. 2011. Handbook of Style and Usage. Manila.

5
implemented over 25 months, beginning on 1 December 2012 with completion targeted for 31 
December 2014. 
 
19.  The Key Indicators publication is produced by a team consisting of ERDI international, 
national, and administrative staff with support from international and national consultants. For 
Key Indicators 2013 and Key Indicators 2014 and their supplements, an estimated 16 person-
months of international consultancy services and 92 person-months of national consultancy 
services will be needed for the entire production process, i.e., for the special chapter, the 
statistical  tables  (MDG,  country,  and  regional),  the  special  supplement,  and  other 
developmental activities related to improving data quality and promoting effective dissemination 
of results and findings.  
 
20.  Consulting services are required to develop the different parts of Key Indicators. For the 
special chapter, international consultants will be preparing background papers and original 
research material related to the theme, and will provide some manuscript and economics editing. 
National consultants will provide specific insight and research into country case studies and 
assist in data cleaning, calculations, and some analytical research.  
 
21.  For  the  statistical  tables—MDG,  regional,  and  country—and  commentaries,  an 
international or national consultant may be engaged to develop the aggregation procedures and 
other methodologies or innovations that will contribute to increasing the interest for users of the 
publication. An international consultant will also be recruited to draft the commentaries. Both 
staff and national consultants will assist in preparing the statistical tables, charts, boxes, and 
commentaries; laying out the text and tables; and copy editing. 
 
22.  For the special supplements, international consultants will work on the analysis and 
write-up for a theme of interest, focusing on an aspect of inclusive growth. National consultants 
will assist in updating, validating, and further researching the indicators; laying out text and 
tables; and manuscript and/or copy editing. 
 
23.  Resource  persons  will  also  be  engaged  to  contribute  as  facilitators,  speakers,  or 
panelists for Key Indicators workshops for the special chapters, supplements, and the statistical 
tables. Travel of ADB staff participating as resource persons in related workshops, conferences, 
or seminars may also be supported, following the appropriate administrative guidelines. 
 
24.  All  consultants  will  be  recruited  individually  and  selected  on  the  basis  of  their 
qualifications  for  the  assignment.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  is  in 
Appendix 4. The international and national consultants, as well as resource persons, to be 
retained will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement of goods or equipment, if any, will be 
done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2013–2014, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

10  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Economists  and  Other  International  Consultants  (international,  intermittent,  12 
person-months)  
 
1.  The  consultants  should  have  a  strong  background  in  development  economics, 
economics,  and/or  other  related  subjects  with  a  good  publication  record  on  structural 
transformation issues. The consultants should also have expertise and/or interests in Asian 
economies. The consultants will  
(i)  conduct  empirical  analysis  that  characterizes  the  structure  and  dynamics  of 
Asia’s economic transformation to promote inclusive and sustainable growth; 
(ii)  examine the impact of structural transformation on different sectors such as 
agriculture, industry, and services as well as on different aspects such as energy 
and education; 
(iii)  provide advice on the direction of research for the special chapter and contribute 
to writing the initial draft of the special chapter, with the following specific tasks:  
(a)  review  draft  outline  of special  chapter  prepared  by  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB) staff and provide comments and suggestions for its finalization; 
(b)  review draft terms of reference for background papers prepared by ADB 
staff and provide comments and suggestions for their finalization;  
(c)  review and comment on draft background papers;  
(d)  attend  workshops  and  provide  comments  and  suggestions  for  the 
finalization of background papers; 
(e)  provide advice to authors of the background papers as required; and 
(f)  draft a paper that will serve as the basis for the introduction to the special 
chapter to be presented in the workshops; and 
(iv)  perform other tasks as may be assigned. 
 
2.  The  outputs  will  include  thematic  commentaries  and/or  background  papers  for  the 
special chapter. 
 
B.     Economists (6 national consultants, intermittent, 12 person-months)  
 
3.  The national consultants should have well-rounded knowledge of policies (in their own 
country) that have strongly influenced the direction and speed of structural transformation. They 
should  also  be  knowledgeable  about  sources  of  reliable  data  pertaining  to  structural 
transformation and have the ability to access and work on these. The consultants will  
(i)  describe  major  policies  and  interventions  that  are  beneficial  to  or  inhibit 
promotion of inclusive and sustainable structural transformation in their country, 
(ii)  synthesize findings in a report, 
(iii)  provide inputs to Economics and Research Department staff and international 
consultants  regarding  policies  and  interventions  relevant  to  structural 
transformation,  
(iv)  present the country papers in the workshops, and 
(v)  perform other tasks as may be assigned. 
 
4.  The outputs will include background papers and/or country-specific case studies for the 
special chapter.

12  Appendix 4 
(vi)  participate  in  meetings  and  assist  in  the  preparation  of  the  Key  Indicators 
commentaries; and 
(vii)  perform other technical and administrative tasks as may be assigned.  
 
9.  The  output  will  include  Key  Indicators  questionnaires,  country  tables,  Millennium 
Development Goal tables, regional tables, and charts and figures in the write-ups, highlights, 
and presentation materials. 
 
E.    Inclusive Growth Expert (international, 2 person-months) 
 
10.  The expert should have a strong background in using socioeconomic indicators and 
national household survey data for policy analysis purposes and must possess excellent writing 
skills.  Preferably,  he  or  she  should  have  experience  with  international  organizations  and 
considerable  research  experience  in  development  policy,  especially  on  economic  growth, 
poverty, and inclusive growth, with particular focus on social sector issues of developing Asia. 
The expert will  
(i)  draft a paper based on original empirical research on a selected theme of the 
FIGI that will serve as basis for the introductory chapter of the Key Indicators 
special supplement from the perspective of inclusive growth in developing Asia;  
(ii)  develop policy implications from the results relevant to inclusive growth;  
(iii)  discuss with the project officer any issues encountered in drafting the paper, and 
finalize the draft report based on discussions and comments; and  
(iv)  perform other tasks as may be assigned. 
 
11.   The outputs will include write-ups for the FIGI. 
 
F.   Economics and Statistics Research Assistants (2 national consultants, 17 person-
months) 
 
12.  The assistants should have a background in economics and/or statistics and experience 
in working with socioeconomic statistics, preferably in the area of official statistics. They should 
possess excellent skills in using Microsoft Excel and preferably have a working knowledge of 
Stata  or  similar  statistical  processing  software.  They  should  be  familiar  with  international 
databases, particularly those related to inclusive growth. They should also be able to document 
procedures and other important information and possess excellent organizational skills. The 
assistants will  
(i)  update the data and identified data sources and metadata (definitions, sources, 
availability, and other relevant information) for all the indicators included in the 
FIGI;  
(ii)  organize the data files of the indicators in a time series database form to facilitate 
data retrieval, as well as understanding and management of data;  
(iii)  conduct additional research in relation to the selected indicators included in the 
FIGI and explore new and/or alternative indicators, if needed;  
(iv)  identify data sources for more disaggregated data for subnational populations for 
selected indicators; 
(v)  prepare data tables, ensure accuracy of data in the tables, and assist in writing 
statistical commentaries and analysis for the 2013 edition of the FIGI; and 
(vi)  perform other tasks as may be assigned. 
 
13.  The outputs will include FIGI statistical tables, charts, and graphs.

Appendix 4  13 
G.    Copy Editor (national or international, intermittent, 2 person-months)  
 
14.  The copy editor shall be responsible for copyediting parts II, III, and IV of the Key 
Indicators publication, including the tables and charts included in the publication, following the 
ADB Handbook of Style and Usage. He or she shall also be responsible for copyediting the 
write-up for the Key Indicators special supplement, including the tables and charts. This will 
include a number of editing rounds of the typeset version until a desired quality is achieved. He 
or she will also make suggestions as to the layout. In particular, the copy editor will 
(i)  reorganize text so that the subject matter is easy to understand and is logically 
presented;  
(ii)  eliminate wordiness and repetition, and reduce ambiguity; 
(iii)  identify obvious errors and point out questionable proper names, bibliographic 
references, and the like, but excluding fact checking; 
(iv)  query discrepancies, possible typographical errors, and non-English terms; 
(v)  edit tables and figures, and recast if required; 
(vi)  ensure that subheadings are consistent and logical; 
(vii)  check references to tables, figures, appendixes, and parts of the text; 
(viii)  edit notes to ensure that the text reference is correct; 
(ix)  edit reference lists; 
(x)  edit the foreword and acknowledgment of the Key Indicators and FIGI; 
(xi)  check final changes; 
(xii)  work closely with the Key Indicators overall coordinator or the project officer of 
the FIGI;  
(xiii)  check and sign off on the layout; and 
(xiv)  perform other tasks as may be assigned. 
 
15.  The outputs will include copyedited parts II, III, and IV of the Key Indicators publication, 
including the tables and charts in the publication. 
 
H.    Graphic Designer (national, intermittent, 1 person-month) 
 
16.  The graphic designer will be responsible for text layout, encoding of corrections, re-
layout, and formatting of graphic elements of Key Indicators, including refining its web version. 
He or she must be skilled in working with Creative Suite 4 (or 5), Microsoft Word, and Microsoft 
Excel. He or she will prepare Adobe InDesign, Illustrator, and PDF files of the interiors and 
covers using original manuscripts submitted in Microsoft Word and Microsoft Excel. In particular, 
the graphics designer will 
(i)  layout the Key Indicators publications, 
(ii)  reformat tables and charts and encode corrections in the main text based on 
corrections received from ERDI staff and consultants, 
(iii)  prepare the final layout of Key Indicators, 
(iv)  encode final text and graphical corrections from ERDI staff and consultants, 
(v)  deliver the final artwork of Key Indicators covers to ERDI for final offset printing, 
(vi)  deliver the web-ready and preflighted consolidated PDF of the publication to 
ERDI, 2 and 
(vii)  perform other tasks as may be assigned.  
 
                                                 
2 Preflighting is a process to check that all the elements needed to accurately reproduce a document are correct and 
strictly follow printing specifications.

14  Appendix 4 
17.  The output is the text layout, encoded corrections, re-layout, and formatted graphic 
elements of Key Indicators and its supplement, including the web version.
